sn35.238:4.1: “Mendicants, suppose there were four lethal poisonous vipers.
sn35.238:4.2: Then a person would come along who wants to live and doesn’t want to die, who wants to be happy and recoils from pain.
sn35.238:4.4: ‘Mister, here are four lethal poisonous vipers. They must be periodically picked up, washed, fed, and put to sleep.
sn35.238:4.5: But when one or other of these four poisonous vipers gets irritated with you, you’ll meet with death or deadly pain.
sn35.238:4.6: So then, mister, do what has to be done.’
sn35.238:5.1: Then that man, terrified of those four poisonous vipers, would flee this way or that.
sn35.238:5.3: ‘Mister, there are five deadly enemies chasing you, thinking: “When we catch sight of him, we’ll murder him right there!”
sn35.238:5.4: So then, mister, do what has to be done.’
sn35.238:6.1: Then that man, terrified of those four poisonous vipers and those five deadly enemies, would flee this way or that.
sn35.238:6.3: ‘Mister, there’s a sixth hidden killer chasing you with a drawn sword, thinking: “When I catch sight of him, I’ll chop off his head right there!”
sn35.238:6.4: So then, mister, do what has to be done.’
sn35.238:7.1: Then that man, terrified of those four poisonous vipers and those five deadly enemies and the hidden killer, would flee this way or that.
sn35.238:7.3: But whatever house he’d enter is vacant, deserted, and empty.
sn35.238:7.4: And whatever vessel he touches is vacant, hollow, and empty.
sn35.238:7.6: ‘Mister, there are bandits who raid villages, and they’re striking now.
sn35.238:7.7: So then, mister, do what has to be done.’
sn35.238:8.1: Then that man, terrified of those four poisonous vipers and those five deadly enemies and the hidden killer and the bandits, would flee this way or that.
sn35.238:8.2: He’d see a large deluge, whose near shore is dubious and perilous, while the far shore is a sanctuary free of peril.
sn35.238:8.3: But there’s no ferryboat or bridge for crossing over.
sn35.238:8.6: ‘Why don’t I gather grass, sticks, branches, and leaves and make a raft? Riding on the raft, and paddling with my hands and feet, I can safely reach the far shore.’
sn35.238:9.1: And so that man did exactly that. Having crossed over and gone beyond, the brahmin stands on the far shore.
sn35.238:10.1: I’ve made up this simile to make a point.
sn35.238:10.3: ‘Four lethal poisonous vipers’ is a term for the four great elements:
sn35.238:10.4: the elements of earth, water, fire, and air.
sn35.238:11.1: ‘Five deadly enemies’ is a term for the five grasping aggregates, that is:
sn35.238:11.2: the grasping aggregates of form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness.
sn35.238:12.1: ‘The sixth hidden killer with a drawn sword’ is a term for relishing and greed.
sn35.238:13.1: ‘Empty village’ is a term for the six interior sense fields.
sn35.238:13.2: If an astute, competent, clever person investigates this through the eye, it appears to them as vacant, hollow, and empty.
sn35.238:13.3: If an astute, competent, clever person investigates this through the ear … nose … tongue … body …
sn35.238:13.4: mind, it appears to them as vacant, hollow, and empty.
sn35.238:14.1: ‘Bandits who raid villages’ is a term for the six exterior sense fields.
sn35.238:14.2: The eye is struck by both agreeable and disagreeable sights.
sn35.238:14.7: mind is struck by both agreeable and disagreeable phenomena.
sn35.238:15.1: ‘Large sea’ is a term for the four floods:
sn35.238:15.2: the floods of sensual pleasures, desire to be reborn, views, and ignorance.
sn35.238:16.1: ‘The near shore that’s dubious and perilous’ is term for identity.
sn35.238:17.1: ‘The far shore, a sanctuary free of peril’ is a term for extinguishment.
sn35.238:18.1: ‘The raft’ is a term for the noble eightfold path, that is:
sn35.238:18.2: right view, right motivation, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right samādhi.
sn35.238:19.1: ‘Paddling with hands and feet’ is a term for being energetic.
sn35.238:20.1: ‘Crossed over, gone beyond, the brahmin stands on the shore’ is a term for a perfected one.”
